children: Sleep disorders have six classifications: insomnia, sleep-related breathing disorders, central disorders of hypersomnolence, circadian rhythm sleep-wake disorders, parasomnias, and sleep-related movement disorders (including restless leg syndrome). For a discussion of insomnia, see

Excessive daytime sleepiness refers to difficulty staying awake and alert during daytime hours. Lack of self-recognition is common and poses a safety hazard if sleepiness occurs while driving or operating machinery. Sleepiness, a cardinal symptom of many sleep disorders, is different from fatigue, which is a lack of energy or sense of exhaustion that prevents mental or physical activity at the desired intensity or pace. Fatigue is unlikely to be solely attributable to a sleep disorder and is more likely to occur in other medical conditions.
Causes of excessive daytime sleepiness can be categorized as extrinsic (circumstantial) or intrinsic (disease-related) processes

Sleepiness can occur acutely when a person is deprived of the 7 to 8 hours of sleep most adults require. Functional impairment resulting from an inadequate amount of sleep is termed insufficient sleep syndrome. It likely is the most common cause of excessive daytime sleepiness and has been associated with cardiovascular disease and metabolic disorders such as glucose intolerance and obesity.

The initial evaluation of excessive daytime sleepiness should include a thorough history to assess the time available for and time spent sleeping before pursuing additional testing. Patients should be questioned about sleep hygiene, the effect of sleepiness on activities, sleep times and duration, sleep environment, napping, caffeine use, and duration of symptoms. In addition, physicians should probe for symptoms of specific sleep disorders (snoring, apneas, leg discomfort, and sleep attacks). A 1- or 2-week diary of the sleep-wake schedule is a simple tool that promotes self-realization of suboptimal sleep habits. A more objective assessment of sleep and wakefulness can be obtained with a wrist actigraph—a device that measures movement and ambient light during a period of 1 or 2 weeks. Wrist-worn consumer fitness products using similar technology may provide useful feedback. Questionnaires such as the Epworth Sleepiness Scale can quantify sleepiness and help gauge the response to treatment.

Objective sleep testing, either in-lab or at-home multichannel recordings, is often indicated when a primary sleep disorder is suggested by the history and physical examination. In certain cases, a multiple sleep latency test—a sleep laboratory–based study that measures the time to sleep during a series of daytime nap opportunities after a normal night of sleep—provides an objective measure of sleepiness and is key to establishing the diagnoses of narcolepsy and idiopathic hypersomnia.

All patients with excessive daytime sleepiness should be counseled about the dangers of drowsy driving and the need to maintain a routine sleep-wake schedule that allows for 7 to 8 hours of sleep per night. Specific treatment depends on the underlying condition. Short-term management of the occasional bout of acute sleepiness may include strategically timed naps or caffeine.
The initial evaluation of excessive daytime sleepiness should include a thorough history to assess the time available for and time spent sleeping before pursuing additional testing.
All patients with excessive daytime sleepiness should be counseled about the dangers of drowsy driving and the need for 7 to 8 hours of sleep per night.

Functional impairment resulting from chronic sleep debt resulting from an inadequate amount of sleep is termed insufficient sleep syndrome; it likely is the most common cause of excessive daytime sleepiness.

Jet lag results when the internal circadian clock is out of phase with the local time after air travel across multiple (typically more than three) time zones. Symptoms occur within one to two days after travel and may include insomnia, daytime sleepiness, and neuropsychiatric impairment. Eastward travel is more difficult to adapt to than westward travel. For short trips (one to two days), remaining on origin time might be preferable, if feasible. For longer trips, adjusting to the destination time may alleviate jet lag. Ways to promote adjustment include avoidance of sleep deprivation and dehydration, as well as bright light therapy starting up to 3 days before travel with the intention of advancing the circadian phase. In-flight hypnotic medications pose a risk for parasomnias (walking while asleep), particularly if alcohol is consumed. Postarrival measures include timed bright light exposure and melatonin, depending on the direction traveled, caffeine intake, and naps.

As much as one fifth of the American work force maintains a job schedule outside the usual day shift hours. Although some people acclimate well to this schedule, many experience excessive sleepiness, mood perturbations, and neurocognitive dysfunction. Symptoms persisting for at least 3 months meet the criteria for shift work sleep disorder. Management should first include counseling that takes into consideration eliminating shift work via a change in work schedule. If this is not feasible, then education about symptom management should be pursued. Interventions to improve daytime sleep may include bright light avoidance in the morning, maintaining a structured sleep-wake pattern (even during nonwork weeks), and use of melatonin, which is of modest benefit in shifting the physiologic sleep cycle. Hypnotic medications are of varying effectiveness and pose the risk for carryover effects into the nighttime work period. Interventions to promote nighttime wakefulness include bright light treatment in the evening before the night shift, caffeinated beverages, wake-promoting stimulants such as modafinil (only if conservative measures have failed), and planned napping during work breaks.

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is defined by sleep interruption resulting from repetitive upper airway narrowing or collapse. These disordered breathing events, captured during sleep testing, are classified as either apneas (complete cessation of airflow for ≥10 seconds) or hypopneas (reductions in airflow), and when these events are divided by total sleep time they make up the apnea-hypopnea index (AHI). Although this frequency-based measure does not incorporate every important OSA outcome (for example, oxyhemoglobin desaturations), the AHI is probably the best composite metric of disease severity. An AHI of 5 to 14 per hour indicates mild OSA, 15 to 30 per hour indicates moderate OSA, and more than 30 per hour indicates severe OSA. The degree of sleepiness does not always correlate with the AHI.
Obstructive sleep apnea is defined by sleep interruption resulting from repetitive upper airway narrowing or collapse.

The apnea-hypopnea index is the total number of apnea and hypopnea events divided by total sleep time and can classify obstructive sleep apnea as mild (5-14 events per hour), moderate (15-30 per hour), or severe (more than 30 per hour).

With sleep onset, pharyngeal muscles acting to maintain upper airway patency relax, resulting in redundancy of the soft tissues that line the airway. Snoring is often a result of this process. The supine position promotes posterior displacement of the tongue, further narrowing the airway lumen. Disordered breathing events are most prominent during rapid eye movement, a stage of sleep characterized by atonia of nearly all muscles with the exception of the extraocular muscles and respiratory diaphragm. The process is terminated with a brief awakening from sleep (microarousal), during which upper airway patency is restored and ventilation resumes, typically followed by resumption of sleep and repetition of the process throughout the nightly sleep period.

Repetitive arousals and disruption of the sleep architecture contribute to the development of excessive daytime sleepiness and neurocognitive symptoms of OSA. Oxyhemoglobin desaturations can be profound, particularly in those with underlying cardiopulmonary disease. Current evidence suggests a causal link between OSA and systemic hypertension. However, relationships with other disorders such as heart failure, cardiac arrhythmias, diabetes mellitus, and mortality are merely associative.

The most important risk factor for OSA is obesity, particularly in those with prominence of adipose tissue in the trunk and neck. The prevalence of OSA increases with age. Alcohol and sedative drugs can exacerbate OSA. Tonsillar hypertrophy, macroglossia, retrognathia and micrognathia, and upper airway mass lesions can contribute to upper airway narrowing.
The most important risk factor for obstructive sleep apnea is obesity.

Sleep-related choking or gasping is probably the most sensitive pretest indicator of OSA. Other symptoms include overnight awakenings, nocturia, morning headaches, and unrefreshing sleep. OSA may be clinically recognized for the first time after a procedure that entails general anesthesia or narcotics manifesting as repeated episodes of postoperative hypoxia or frank respiratory failure.

The most important established consequence of OSA is excessive daytime sleepiness. Collateral history from a family member as well as questionnaires such as the Epworth Sleepiness Scale can help identify excessive daytime sleepiness. Neuropsychiatric symptoms are common, including mood alterations, difficulty concentrating, and problems completing tasks at school or the workplace.

Objective testing is required for a diagnosis of OSA. Physical examination findings (crowded oropharynx, neck circumference) and questionnaires might increase pretest probability and guide decision-making about testing, but alone they are insufficiently sensitive or specific. Overnight pulse oximetry is also poorly discriminative, but in those who are asymptomatic with a low pretest probability, normal overnight oximetry might support the decision to avoid further testing. In-laboratory polysomnography is the gold standard test for mission-critical workers, patients with complicated OSA, and patients with comorbid conditions such as heart failure, neuromuscular disease, and advanced pulmonary disease in which diagnostic and treatment algorithms are more complex. Home sleep apnea testing, which is less costly and less resource intensive than polysomnography, is increasingly employed. Home sleep apnea testing does not measure electroencephalographic sleep like polysomnography does, but using respiratory tools or noninvasive measurements of vascular tone, pulse oximetry, and an accelerometer to detect posture, it is highly sensitive in diagnosing OSA in those with a pretest likelihood of moderate to severe disease. Home sleep apnea testing is less reliable in those felt to have milder disease.
In-laboratory testing is recommended for mission-critical workers, patients with comorbid medical conditions, and patients with complicated obstructive sleep apnea.
Home sleep testing may be most appropriate in patients without underlying cardiopulmonary or neuromuscular disease who have at least moderate to severe obstructive sleep apnea.

The strongest indication for treatment of OSA is excessive daytime sleepiness, which generally improves with effective therapy. Neurocognitive and mood symptoms are probably indications for treatment. In patients who perform mission-critical work (truck drivers, pilots), the threshold for treatment may be lower than for others. The role of treatment in otherwise healthy or asymptomatic individuals is undecided. Several treatment options exist for OSA, the efficacy of which are generally based on the ability to reduce, if not abolish, apneas and hypopneas. Positive airway pressure therapy typically reduces the AHI toward zero by splinting open the upper airway. However, because the AHI does not always correlate with important outcomes in OSA, other treatments may adequately manage OSA for a given patient, even in the face of residual sleep apnea. Referral to a sleep surgeon for upper airway surgery should be considered for patients with a BMI <40 who are intolerant of positive airway pressure therapy.

Positive airway pressure (and possibly oral appliances) has been shown to modestly reduce blood pressure in hypertensive patients with OSA, but the effect of treatment to manage comorbid cardiovascular disease or to prevent major cardiovascular events is thus far unproven. There is no effective pharmacologic treatment for OSA.

OSA severity improves with weight loss. In minimally symptomatic patients with mild OSA, weight loss might be preferred therapy. Additional measures for mild OSA include reducing alcohol intake before bedtime, avoiding sedating medications, and avoiding a supine posture if OSA is position-dependent. Referral to a bariatric surgeon should be considered for patients with BMI ≥35 who have not benefited from or are intolerant of positive airway pressure therapy.
Obstructive sleep apnea severity improves with weight loss.

Positive airway pressure remains the most effective therapy for preventing disordered breathing events, alleviating symptoms, and improving sleep-related quality of life in patients who have OSA. It acts by pressurizing the upper airway to maintain luminal patency.

The diagnosis by home sleep apnea testing is coupled to treatment with auto-adjusting positive airway pressure, which uses a computer algorithm to detect and overcome upper airway resistance in real time. Auto-adjusting positive airway pressure and continuous positive airway pressure are considered therapeutic equivalents in terms of reducing the AHI, improving adherence to treatment, and improving OSA symptoms. Bilevel positive airway pressure, which delivers separate inspiratory and expiratory pressures to augment alveolar ventilation, has no role in OSA without a hypoventilation syndrome.

The effectiveness of positive airway pressure therapy hinges on patient adherence. Educational programs can help, as can direct-to-patient reports wirelessly transmitted from the device to smartphones or computers. Adverse effects such as xerostomia and nasal dryness and congestion can be ameliorated by in-line humidification. Intranasal glucocorticoids or anticholinergics may be useful for recalcitrant nasal congestion or rhinitis. Modified pressure profiles that vary pressure over a respiratory cycle may enhance comfort. Proper mask fit enhances comfort and mitigates air leak.
Positive airway pressure remains the most effective therapy for preventing disordered breathing events and alleviating symptoms in patients who have obstructive sleep apnea.
Auto-adjusting positive airway pressure and continuous positive airway pressure are considered therapeutic equivalents for reducing the apnea-hypopnea index.

Oral appliances increase upper airway caliber primarily by exerting traction to advance the mandible. They do not reduce the AHI or increase oxygen levels as reliably as positive airway pressure, and they are generally avoided in more severe cases of OSA. However, these appliances have demonstrated good control of mild to moderate OSA and improvement in symptoms such as daytime sleepiness. Oral appliances may have a higher rate of adherence than continuous positive airway pressure.

Although surgical procedures are generally not first-line therapy for OSA, maxillomandibular advancement significantly improves the AHI, even in severe disease, and can be considered for patients with a BMI <40 who do not benefit from or tolerate positive airway pressure therapy. Soft palatal procedures such as uvulopalatopharyngoplasty are of limited efficacy but may be an option in select patients. Tonsillectomy in adults may sometimes be effective, depending on the amount of extratonsillar soft tissue crowding the upper airway. Tracheotomy is an effective—although uncommonly used—treatment of OSA, limited by patient acceptance and aesthetics.
Surgical treatments for obstructive sleep apnea can be considered for patients who do not benefit from or tolerate airway pressure therapy.

A hypoglossal nerve stimulator been shown to improve the AHI in some patients. Implanted in the chest wall, it synchronizes with the respiratory cycle to contract the tongue muscles during inspiration. The patients who are most likely to benefit from this treatment are yet to be determined.

A nasal end-expiratory positive airway pressure device applied to the nasal openings via an adhesive has also been shown to reduce the AHI in some, but not all, patients. Supplemental oxygen is not recommended as primary therapy for OSA.

Central sleep apnea (CSA) syndromes are defined by pauses in airflow caused by loss of output from the central respiratory generators in the brainstem to the respiratory muscles, resulting in lack of respiratory effort. Under normal circumstances, a steady state exists in which ventilation maintains arterial P
in the normal range. In CSA syndromes, the response to arterial P
is exaggerated, resulting in ventilatory overshoot, hyperventilation, and reduction of the arterial P

to a level at which respiratory efforts cease. This central apnea further destabilizes ventilation and perpetuates the process. On polysomnography, central apnea is identified by the absence of respiratory effort associated with loss of airflow for at least 10 seconds.
Central sleep apnea syndromes are defined by pauses in airflow caused by loss of output from the central respiratory generators in the brainstem, resulting in lack of respiratory effort.

Primary or idiopathic CSA, in which no risk factors are identified, is uncommon. Comorbid illnesses that predispose to instability of the ventilatory control system are the most common risk factors for CSA. The most prevalent association is between CSA and heart failure, which manifests as Cheyne-Stokes breathing, characterized by a crescendo-decrescendo pattern of ventilation. Atrial fibrillation, both in the setting of heart failure and in those with normal left ventricular systolic function, is a risk factor for CSA.

Known for their respiratory depressant effects in high doses, opioid analgesics are also associated with CSA. Opioids have destabilizing effects on ventilation, resulting in CSA and a chaotic breathing rhythm.

Approximately 10 percent of patients with OSA treated with positive airway pressure exhibit “treatment-emergent CSA,” the significance of which is a matter of debate. In many, the central apneas dissipate as patients acclimate to positive airway pressure therapy.
Other risk factors for CSA include stroke, brainstem lesions, and possibly kidney injury. High-altitude periodic breathing is a form of CSA.

It can be difficult to determine which symptoms are specific to CSA and which are associated with the comorbid condition or conditions. In-lab polysomnography is required to accurately diagnose CSA. It should also be noted that although the AHI is traditionally used to describe the severity of CSA, it has not been validated as a predictor of important clinical outcomes in CSA as it has been in OSA. Finally, abnormal oximetry does not reliably discriminate between OSA and CSA.

Initial management of CSA should target modifiable risk factors. For example, reduction or elimination of opioids improves CSA. Medical optimization of heart failure has been shown to improve CSA and Cheyne-Stokes breathing, although it remains controversial as to whether CSA is an independent risk factor for worsened prognosis in those with heart failure.

Sleep-related symptoms probably represent an indication for treatment. Continuous positive airway pressure may occasionally be useful, especially in patients with overlapping OSA. Adaptive servo-ventilation is a form of positive airway pressure therapy that effectively suppresses CSA. However, a large trial showed an unexpected increase in mortality in patients with CSA and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction treated with ASV. Unlike OSA, oxygen during sleep may be indicated for patients with CSA who have hypoxia during sleep, as well as for those who cannot use or tolerate continuous positive airway pressure.
Initial management of central sleep apnea should target modifiable risk factors such as heart failure and elimination of opioids.
Sleep-related hypoventilation syndromes are associated with advanced COPD, obesity, and restrictive lung diseases, neuromuscular disorders, and other diseases

. These conditions are defined by impaired gas exchange during wakefulness further compromised with sleep, especially during the muscle atonia of rapid eye movement. Capnometry (measurement of either transcutaneous or end-tidal carbon dioxide levels) is increasingly used to confirm hypoventilation during sleep, although oxygenation criteria are also used to diagnose sleep-related hypoventilation syndromes. Sustained reductions in oxyhemoglobin saturation in the setting of a compatible medical condition signify a hypoventilation syndrome. Obstructive sleep apnea may or may not be an associated feature.

Sleep-related hypoventilation syndromes are defined by impaired gas exchange during wakefulness further compromised with sleep; common associated conditions include advanced COPD, obesity hypoventilation syndrome, and restrictive lung diseases related to kyphoscoliosis or neuromuscular disorders.

Patients with severe COPD often exhibit sleep-related hypoventilation. In addition to optimization of COPD therapy, supplemental oxygen is often used. The noninvasive pressure support of bilevel positive airway pressure can be used if hypercapnia is confirmed. In the overlap syndrome in which OSA is superimposed on COPD, continuous positive airway pressure therapy has been shown to decrease mortality rates.

Obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS) results from a combination of the mechanical load on the respiratory pump and blunting of the ventilatory response to carbon dioxide. The hallmark of OHS is daytime hypercapnia, defined as a P
greater than 45 mm Hg (5.9 kPa). OSA is usually but not always superimposed. Biventricular heart failure, pulmonary hypertension, and volume overload are common.

Weight loss is essential and consideration can be given to bariatric surgery. Positive airway pressure therapy is indicated. The American Thoracic Society recommends continuous positive airway pressure therapy for stable ambulatory patients diagnosed with OHS and concomitant severe OSA (AHI more than 30 events per hour). For hospitalized patients with suspected OHS-related respiratory failure, the American Thoracic Society recommends either bilevel positive airway pressure, with or without a backup respiratory rate, or volume-targeted pressure support. This therapy should be continued after hospital discharge until the patient can be evaluated with polysomnography and titrated with the appropriate positive pressure support. Supplemental oxygen may need to be added.
The hallmark of obesity hypoventilation syndrome is daytime hypercapnia, defined as an arterial P
Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation devices are often prescribed to alleviate sleep-related symptoms and support blood oxygen levels in patients with neuromuscular disorders

. Bilevel positive airway pressure or volume-assured devices (average volume-assured pressure support), either with or without supplemental oxygen, are indicated once there is evidence of daytime hypercapnia indicative of chronic respiratory failure. Polysomnography may aid in optimizing machine and oxygen settings and in assessing concomitant sleep disorders, but it is not always needed. Tracheostomy and home mechanical ventilation are effective and may be appropriate for some patients. Supplemental oxygen may further depress ventilation in patients with respiratory muscle weakness and should generally not be prescribed without adjunctive ventilatory support, either by noninvasive means or by tracheostomy.
Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation devices are often prescribed to alleviate sleep-related symptoms and support blood oxygen levels in patients with neuromuscular disorders.
Caples SM, Rowley JA, Prinsell JR, et al. Surgical modifications of the upper airway for obstructive sleep apnea in adults: a systematic review and meta-analysis. Sleep. 2010;33:1396-407.
Cowie MR, Woehrle H, Wegscheider K, et al. Adaptive servo-ventilation for central sleep apnea in systolic heart failure. N Engl J Med. 2015;373:1095-105.

Hudgel DW, Patel SR, Ahasic AM, et al; American Thoracic Society Assembly on Sleep and Respiratory Neurobiology. The role of weight management in the treatment of adult obstructive sleep apnea. an official American Thoracic Society clinical practice guideline. Am J Respir Crit Care Med. 2018;198:e70-e87.

Kapur VK, Auckley DH, Chowdhuri S, et al. Clinical practice guideline for diagnostic testing for adult obstructive sleep apnea: an American Academy of Sleep Medicine clinical practice guideline. J Clin Sleep Med. 2017;13:479-504.

Kent D, Stanley J, Aurora RN, et al. Referral of adults with obstructive sleep apnea for surgical consultation: an American Academy of Sleep Medicine clinical practice guideline. J Clin Sleep Med. 2021;17(12):2499-2505.

Mokhlesi B, Masa JF, Brozek JL, et al. Evaluation and management of obesity hypoventilation syndrome. an official American Thoracic Society clinical practice guideline. Am J Respir Crit Care Med. 2019;200:e6-e24.

Patil SP, Ayappa IA, Caples SM, et al. Treatment of adult obstructive sleep apnea with positive airway pressure: an American Academy of Sleep Medicine systematic review, meta-analysis, and GRADE assessment. J Clin Sleep Med. 2019;15:301-334.

Ramar K, Dort LC, Katz SG, et al. Clinical practice guideline for the treatment of obstructive sleep apnea and snoring with oral appliance therapy: an update for 2015. J Clin Sleep Med. 2015;11:773-827.

title.__html: Extrinsic and Intrinsic Causes of Excessive Daytime Sleepiness

children: Extrinsic and Intrinsic Causes of Excessive Daytime Sleepiness
Insufficient sleep duration (or inadequate opportunity for sleep)
Circadian rhythm disturbance (shift work sleep disorder, jet lag)
Drug-, substance-, psychiatric-, or medical condition–related hypersomnia
Sleep-disordered breathing syndromes, such as obstructive sleep apnea and central sleep apnea
Restless leg syndrome and periodic limb movement disorder
Circadian rhythm sleep disorders (misalignment of the intrinsic circadian timing with the desired sleep schedule; for example, dementia and blindness)
Fixed pressure derived from an in-lab titration attended by a technician
Range of pressure delivered to maintain upper airway patency, determined by a proprietary computer algorithm
Inspiratory pressure support delivered over and above a minimum expiratory pressure, derived from an in-lab titration
OSA when CPAP fails (including patient intolerance)
Range of bilevel pressures determined by a proprietary computer algorithm
Breath-by-breath adjustment of inspiratory pressure support and back-up rate determined by a proprietary computer algorithm; expiratory pressure set by a technician
CSA (including mixed CSA and OSA); do not use in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction
Inspiratory and expiratory pressures determined by a proprietary algorithm

footnotes: APAP = auto-adjusting positive airway pressure; ASV = adaptive servo ventilation; BPAP = bilevel positive airway pressure; CPAP = continuous positive airway pressure; CSA = central sleep apnea; OSA = obstructive sleep apnea.
